title: Parametric Fan Blade Modelling & Body-Force Methods
impact: Developed a semi-analytical Body-Force Method for aerodynamic simulations, automating the geometry-to-model workflow using B-splines.
summary: Focuses on parametric modeling of fan blades and the implementation of body-force terms for efficient aerodynamic analysis, significantly reducing computational overhead compared to full-scale RANS.
problem: Full-scale RANS simulations for fan stages are computationally expensive and slow for parametric design studies.
approach: Replace explicit blade geometry with source terms (Body-Force Model) based on parametric blade profiles.
methods: Python-based geometry generation using B-splines; semi-analytical force calculation; automated mesh/model generation.
validation: Comparison with detailed RANS data to ensure force distribution accuracy.
results: Created a robust workflow for rapid aerodynamic assessment of fan configurations.
learnings: Advanced parametric modeling; deep understanding of BFM formulations.

title: Mechanical Testing of Lightweight Sandwich Panels
impact: Engineered structural validation for eVTOL battery module compression plates using calibrated nonlinear FEM and UTM testing.
summary: Performed quasi-static pull-out and in-plane shear testing of self-tapping inserts in CFRP-Foam-FR4 sandwich structures. Developed a calibrated nonlinear FEM using Simcenter FEA with orthotropic laminate definitions.
problem: Validate the structural integrity of battery module compression plates under specific load introduction points for an eVTOL aircraft.
approach: Parallel experimental and numerical approach: characterization through UTM testing followed by FEM correlation.
methods: Quasi-static testing of 12 joint configurations; cohesive zone modeling in Simcenter for load-displacement replication.
validation: Comparison of experimental load-displacement curves with FEM results to calibrate material and joint models.
results: Identified optimal pilot hole sizes and thread types for maximizing pull-out strength in sandwich composites.
learnings: Advanced understanding of joint behavior in thin CFRP skins and foam cores; proficiency in Simcenter FEA.
next_steps: Testing under dynamic/fatigue loading conditions and high-temperature environments.

title: Aerodynamics of Distributed Electric Propulsion (DEP) Aircraft
impact: Modeled and simulated a DEP-modified Boeing 737-800, investigating lift/drag improvements and wake interaction effects.
summary: Investigated the aerodynamic trade-offs of replacing conventional turbofans with wing-mounted DEP units, focusing on lift enhancement and winglet optimization.
problem: Conventional aircraft struggle with efficiency at low speeds; DEP offers potential for high-lift enhancement and reduced noise.
approach: Replace conventional engines with an array of smaller electric fans and analyze the aerodynamic impact on the wing.
methods: CAD modeling in SolidWorks; high-fidelity meshing in HyperMesh; steady-state RANS simulations in Ansys Fluent.
validation: Compared baseline 737-800 configurations with DEP variants to isolate the 'blown wing' effect.
results: Achieved significant lift coefficient increase at high angles of attack; identified drag penalties associated with unit nacelles.
learnings: Mastery of CFD workflows and high-fidelity meshing; deep dive into aero-propulsion integration.
next_steps: Unsteady simulations to capture propeller-wing interaction more accurately.

title: High-Lift Airfoil Performance: RANS & XFOIL Validation
impact: Validated high-lift airfoil performance using multiple fidelity solvers, comparing RANS k-omega SST with viscous-inviscid interaction codes.
summary: Detailed aerodynamic study of a high-lift airfoil, investigating transition modeling and stall characteristics.
problem: Accurately predicting stall and max lift coefficient in high-lift configurations.
approach: Multi-fidelity comparison between RANS and XFOIL.
methods: Grid sensitivity study; transition modeling (Gamma-Re-Theta); polar generation.
results: Identified separation bubbles and stall mechanisms; confirmed solver reliability for specific flight regimes.
learnings: Transition physics; RANS solver tuning; aerodynamic validation best practices.

title: Subsurface Defect Mapping Using GPR
impact: Detected and sized ~40cm subsurface foam defects in concrete with high accuracy using Ground Penetrating Radar and signal processing.
summary: Executed non-destructive inspection of concrete structures to map subsurface defects, calibrating dielectric properties and generating B- and C-scan profiles.
problem: Detecting internal flaws in thick structures without destructive access.
approach: Use GPR for high-frequency electromagnetic wave reflection analysis.
methods: Calibration via backwall referencing; data collection across 64 scan paths; signal processing in RADAN 7.
validation: Verification of defect size and depth using Time-of-Flight (TOF) and permittivity calculations.
results: Successfully mapped a 40cm foam defect at 5cm depth; analyzed system accuracy and limitations.
learnings: Experience with GPR hardware and signal processing software; understanding of wave propagation in dielectric media.
next_steps: Integration of automated robotic scanning for larger surfaces.

title: Optimized Additive Manufacturing: RC Transport Vehicle
impact: Won top place for a 3D-printed RC car capable of transporting a full water bottle; followed by an exclusive BMW factory visit.
summary: High-performance functional prototyping focusing on weight optimization and load-bearing capacity using FDM printing.
problem: Carry a 500g payload on a lightweight 3D-printed chassis.
approach: Topology optimization and functional integration of wheels and chassis.
methods: NX-based design; material property testing; iterative prototyping.
results: Secured top placement in group challenge.
learnings: Design for Additive Manufacturing (DfAM); load-path optimization.
next_steps: Integration of sensors for autonomous navigation.

title: Spacecraft Power Subsystem Architecture
impact: Architected the end-to-end power system for a LEO debris-tracking satellite, including orbital energy balance and hardware sizing.
summary: Designed generation, storage, and distribution systems for an AI-based LEO mission, selecting mission-critical hardware and performing energy balance modeling.
problem: Ensure continuous power supply for high-demand AI processing on a limited LEO cube-sat platform.
approach: System-level modeling of generation vs consumption throughout the orbital cycle.
methods: Orbital mechanics for solar flux calculation; component selection (EaglePicher batteries, Sparkwing arrays).
validation: Worse-case scenario analysis (eclipse duration, peak load).
results: Defined a robust 60W power bus with 20% margin for all mission phases.
learnings: Space hardware standards and orbital energy budget workflows.
next_steps: Integration of thermal management constraints into the power model.

title: Baja SAE ATV Design & Integration
impact: Engineered and assembled a Baja buggy frame with double-wishbone suspension, successfully validated against performance benchmarks.
summary: Designed and fabricated core subsystems for a high-performance off-road vehicle, focusing on structural integrity and suspension geometry.
problem: Develop a lightweight yet durable chassis for extreme off-road competition.
approach: Iterative design focusing on occupant safety and vehicle dynamics.
methods: Chassis modeling; suspension kinematics optimization; manual jig assembly and welding support.
validation: Structural validation through stress testing and track performance.
results: Completed vehicle integration with successful endurance testing.
learnings: Practical manufacturing skills; suspension geometry; team-based engineering.
next_steps: Weight reduction through carbon-fiber body panels.
